Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2011 08:26AM BooksRule wrote: Dawn: I had a mammogram on a Wednesday.  They called me back into the exam room before I could get re-dressed.  They took more pictures.  They took me right into another room for an US. Then, I came back later that afternoon for a needle biopsy.  There was a three-week gap from that until I met with the BS (on a Tuesday).  I then had an excisional biopsy the next day (not because my case was an emergency or anything--she just had an opening and I took it).  I got my results (B9) that next Tuesday. I would think that if they saw something on the mammo/US that needs further investigation (such as with some type of biopsy) you would at least be informed that further action should be taken, even if they don't schedule any further testing until after the holidays.  I guess it will all depend on what they see and how full everyone's schedules are getting.  I would certainly hope that if they see something that would need some type of biopsy, you would not be left in the dark until after the holidays and then get a phone call or letter that says,  'Oh, by the way, you need to have.......[fill in the blank with whatever test they need].  Please give us a call to schedule, yadda, yadda, yadda'. I know how you feel.  It's hard to enjoy the upcoming holidays with things like this hanging over your head. Lisa
Posts.Title: How long did you wait between mammo and biopsy? Dawnsigkap Tenmom

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2011 01:12PM BooksRule wrote: I had a radial scar removed through an excisional biopsy about a month ago.  I was advised to have it removed because a radial scar can mimic breast cancer.  Even though the needle biopsy came back benign, it needed to be removed since a needle biopsy takes such a small sample that there is always a fear that some bad cells can be missed.  Removing it is the only way to insure that everything that can possibly be bad is taken out. I knew my BIRADS rating (5) and my research told me that this was bad.  I also 'googled' (always a bad idea to rely on Dr. Google) radial scars and didn't like what I read.  Almost every site's information contradicted the previous one.  I was really confused.  About the only thing that they all seemed to agree on was that radial scars should be removed.  And, among other risk factors, my mom and maternal aunt were breast cancer survivors.  I hoped for the best but prepared myself for the worst (if that is ever possible).  However, in my particular case, everything worked out okay.  The radial scar was removed and everything came back benign. So, it's scary, but the outcome is not always bad.  Arm yourself with good information (from reliable websites such as this one) and make a list of questions to ask your doctor.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Radial Scar ?'s cemjo3 marie5890

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2011 03:42PM BooksRule wrote: I've had a radial scar removed (see my Oct. 11 post above).  I think that a radial scar is more of a lesion than a lump.  I'm not exactly sure how deep my radial scar was, but it probably wasn't too deep.  I have a fairly well-healed scar that's around an inch and a half long.  I don't think they took out much at all.  But I'm well-endowed, so they could probably have taken a lot more before I'd notice!  :)   Except for the scar, I look the same. I didn't have much pain at all.  I mainly had some trouble recovering from the anesthesia (I'd never had anything but a local before), so it was a couple of days before I got over my dry mouth and vertigo.  But each person reacts differently from anesthesia.  Most have no problems at all.  I had more pain from the nurse's (tech's?) efforts trying to get my IV in than from the surgery recovery. I had my surgery on a Wednesday, and I think I could have gone back to work on Friday if I hadn't had those anesthesia problems.  I took the rest of the week off and went back on Monday. I think it's a good thing to have a radial scar removed.  I personally didn't want it lingering in me! Good luck!
Posts.Title: Radial Scar ?'s cemjo3 marie5890

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2011 02:22PM BooksRule wrote: At least you're getting the biopsy done before Thanksgiving, so that's one thing you won't have to be worrying about.  I know that you'll be worrying about results, and the whole process is scary, but I hope that you can try to relax and enjoy Thanksgiving a little.  Maybe the holiday won't delay your results any longer than usual. Sending good vibes and please update when you have news!

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2011 05:18PM BooksRule wrote: Okay, I have to chime in here-- At the Imaging Center where I got my mammogram, there was a cartoon taped to the file cabinet in the imaging room.  It showed a woman tech pointing to a mammogram-type machine that had the plates set really low--a little below waist level.  There was a man standing beside it in his underwear who had a terrified look on his face.  The caption read something like:  'Now, just put it between these two plates and we can get started'. Hee!
Posts.Title: Scared, alone, waiting for results alaskadiana profbee

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2011 03:29PM BooksRule wrote: It might be a hematoma.  I still have a little scabby spot where I had my needle biopsy weeks ago.  I also have a hard lumpy place where I had my excisional biopsy.  However, I'm not too concerned about it since I'm assuming that it's either scar tissue or a hematoma.  As long as it's not red, or hot, or infected-looking I'm not going to worry.  I still get a twinge now and then when I sleep on that side, but that is slowly going away. Since you have an appointment with the breast surgeon soon, you can ask about it.  But if it's not really painful or appears inflamed or infected, it's probably alright Please let us know how everything goes!
Posts.Title: Should I Be Worried Lme002 Lme002

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2011 01:01PM BooksRule wrote: They didn't numb me up at all before my wire insertion (they said that the shot to numb me would hurt worse than just having the wire inserted).  It wasn't too painful--felt just like getting a shot.  The part that was the most uncomfortable was having to sit 'pinned' in the mammo machine for around 5 minutes (without moving) so that they could make sure that the wire was in the right place.  That wasn't too pleasant, but manageable.  They taped the wire down and took me back to my room.  I had general for the procedure itself so I didn't feel a thing.  I think that the most painful part of the whole experience was when the nurse was trying to put the IV in.  She had trouble finding a vein (and I've always been told I have really good ones, ha ha!) and had to end up putting it on the inside of my wrist instead of on the top of my hand.  I had a bruise for several days!
Posts.Title: Should I Be Worried Lme002 Lme002

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2011 02:49PM BooksRule wrote: I used to have great veins (at least that's what they always told me when I donated blood).  But when I started going to a general practitioner for regular checkups (which include blood being drawn for labwork) my veins have been 'not as great'.  What made the whole IV insertion more perilous was that while she was trying to get the IV in there were two hospital workmen right behind her working on the automatic doors that separated the pre-op area from the recovery room (there had been a power failure the day before and the doors had a glitch in them).  One of them backed into her just as she got ready to stab me with the needle.  Of course, I just had to lay there and look at the ceiling (I don't fear the sight of blood unless it's my own). Fun times!
Posts.Title: Should I Be Worried Lme002 Lme002

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2012 08:02AM BooksRule wrote: A year ago September I had an excisional biopsy done on a suspicious area.  It was thought to be a radial scar, but because (like someone else has said) it can mimic cancer (and can hide cancer cells) it is always best to remove them.  I was really scared because I was given a BIRADS 5 rating.  I did a lot of research and learned more than I ever wanted to know about radial scars.  I also found out that mine was actually called a 'complex sclerosing lesion', which is just a fancy name for a radial scar that is of a certain size.  It turned out to be totally benign.  I know it's scary, but the waiting is the hardest part! Also, I went in for my annual mammogram last week--I'm never, never going to postpone those again--and no problems were found.  Hopefully, it'll continue this way.
Posts.Title: Possibly Radial Scar or cancer with Needle Biospy tomorrow Kimbr7 BLinthedesert

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2011 03:49PM BooksRule wrote: Lme002-- How are you doing?  You are in my thoughts. Try to relax and take it easy.
Posts.Title: Should I Be Worried Lme002 Lme002

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2011 01:07PM BooksRule wrote: I was diagnosed with what looked like a 'radial scar' a few weeks ago.  This is a benign condition (a needle biopsy came back benign), but because a radial scar can mimic BC on mammograms, the only way to be absolutely sure is to take it out (excisional biopsy).  I did a little research and came to the conclusion that I probably actually had a 'complex sclerosing lesion' (which is a radial scar that is over a certain size).  I had the excisional and everything came out okay (and I was a BIRADS 5, which doesn't usually come out okay!).  Do you know what your BIRADS score is? Most of the time, the results are benign--they just want to be absolutely sure, and an excisional biopsy is considered to be the 'gold standard' of making sure, if I understand correctly. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Should I Be Worried Lme002 Lme002

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2011 01:05PM - edited Nov 22, 2011 01:06PM by BooksRule I was lucky that I was able to have my excisional biopsy the day after I saw the surgeon (she had an opening).  However, the week between the surgery and my follow-up with her (when I got my results) was a very long week.  I took a couple of days off from work after (the surgery was on a Wednesday, so I didn't go back to work until Monday), and I just lounged around and read some not-so-great-literature (but entertaining) books and watched some mindless (but also entertaining) TV.  When I'm upset I tend to either sleep or re-read some of my favorite books.  This really helped pass the time.  It's difficult not to dwell on the 'what ifs', but I hope that you can relax a little.  My results were benign (which was a total shocker, because I was also a BIRAD 5 and had begun planning for the worst-case scenario), so I hope for benign results for both of you--Eileen and kite.

Sending you good vibes!  (and a virtual hug!)  {{{{{{{hug}}}}}}}
Posts.Title: biopsy Eileenohio DebConway

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2011 03:40PM - edited Nov 7, 2011 03:41PM by BooksRule I did.  It was thought to be a 'radial scar' (also called a 'complex sclerosing lesion') which is benign, but because it looks identical to BC on a scan and can lead to BC being mis-identified as a radial scar (and a radial scar can also hide some cancer cells) I was given a Birads 5.  After an excisional biopsy, the path report came back benign. So, it certainly can and does happen.  And, I can definitely identify with your fear and anxiety.
